title: 103_hr1072
content: The "Investment for America Act" reinstates the 10-percent domestic investment tax credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Investment for America Act reinstates the 10% domestic investment tax credit for property placed in service after December 31, 1992. Domestic property must be completed in the United States with at least 60% of its basis attributable to value added within the country. The term "United States" includes Puerto Rico and US possessions. The Investment for America Act reinstates the 10% domestic investment tax credit for property placed in service after December 31, 1992. Section 11813 of the Revenue Reconciliation Act of 1990 is repealed, and a new credit for purchases of domestic durable goods is introduced in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Investment for America Act reinstates a 7% tax credit for individuals who purchase domestic durable goods, with a limit of $1,000 per year. Domestic durable goods must be completed in the United States with at least 60% of the property's basis attributable to value added within the country. The Investment for America Act reinstates a 7% tax credit for individuals purchasing domestic durable goods, capped at $1,000 per year. A new item is added to the table of sections for subpart A after section 22. The Investment for America Act reinstates a 7% tax credit for purchasing domestic durable goods, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1992. Additionally, a new section is added for a tax credit on costs incurred in buying American-made passenger vehicles. The tax credit allows individuals to claim qualified payments made for purchasing domestically produced automobiles after December 31, 1992. This includes State or local sales tax and interest on loans secured by the vehicle. The tax credit allows individuals to claim payments for purchasing domestically produced automobiles for personal, nonbusiness use. The automobile must be more than 60 percent produced and assembled in the United States to qualify. No double benefit is allowed for payments eligible for this credit. Sec. 24 states that certain costs incurred in purchasing an American-made passenger vehicle are eligible for a tax credit. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, Section 5 discusses the placement of "Made in America" labels on products. No product can claim to be made in America unless it is registered with the Department of Commerce, with 60% of the product manufactured in the US and final assembly taking place in the US. Products must be registered within 12 months of regulations being issued. Fraudulent use of labels will result in penalties. The product must meet specific criteria to be labeled as "made in America," with penalties for fraudulent use of such labels, including civil fines up to $100,000 and injunctive relief. The Secretary must establish regulations for product registration within 12 months of this Act's enactment. Definitions include "label" as any written or graphic matter on a product, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of Commerce.
